Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Group Dynamics and Success in Science and Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how to foster the best science, given that most scientific research is done by teams. The research investigates human behavioral patterns that indicate the production of impactful research and the ability to attract grant funding. The objective is to discern characteristics of how research communities develop, form and operate to introduce novel ideas with significant impact. Results make the point that scientific success transcends institutional group boundaries and is a matter of larger communities that coalesce and have a high turnover of novel topics and members. The key objective of this project is a first quantification of patterns of human group dynamics and diversity of scientific content on scientific success in terms of garnering grant support and providing impactful science. Since NSF supports research at many different scientific frontiers, our results may allow the detection of patterns that are valid across many scientific fields.

This project models a corpus of millions of research papers, integrating grant information of diverse scientific fields and scientific content. Research publications are used to construct co-authorship networks in different time windows and scientific fields. Groups in such networks will be detected by the use of contemporary clustering methods that will point to fission/fusion patterns of groups. Project data covering the last 25 years of funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) and will be integrated with content information from the body of research publications. Results make the point that scientific success transcends institutional group boundaries and is a matter of larger communities that coalesce, split and have a high turnover of novel topics and members.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The underlying objective of the project is to investigate the changes in the composition of research communities that are indicative of scientific impact. In other words we wanted to find evolutionary patterns in the composition and emergence of groups of scientists that make them more/less prone to scientific sucess, such as introducing disruptive new ideas or moving a field forward. In more detail, we considered groups of scientists that penned research publications together based on a large corpus of millions of research papers covering 1999-2018. Based on these groups we were looking into so-called fission-fusion patterns that emerge in different consecutive time periods such as groups emerging, disappearing, coalescing and fragmenting and correlate their presence with the propensity to introduce new topics and garner grant support. To carry out these anaylses, we obtained data from the Elsevier publishing house that captures millions of research publications over the last decades. 

Looking into several fission-fusion patterns (such as splits, mergers, growth, contraction, birth, death and unchanged), we observed that mostly newly born teams were increasingly provoding disruptive and consolidating research at the same time. Such an observation was highly peculiar as previous observations indicate that successful teams are a delicate mixture of incumbents and newcomers. We concluded that While our born groups certainly indicate the presence of researchers that have not published before, the relative absence of incumbents was noteworthy, pointing us to the necessity to reconsider the way we determine such group-based evolutionary patterns. In other words, current patterns only account for authors that have been present in consecutive years, dis-accounting for authors that vanish and appear for the first time. We expect that relaxing the conditions for detecting evolutionary patterns will change the underlying distribution of evolutionary patterns, allowing us to find a clearer picture which dynamics are conducive to scientific success. While funding through the EAGER grant for this project has ended, we continue with the underlying research.
